data.text: Contents
Introduction

Enterococci  are  an  increasingly  common  cause  of  healthcare  associated infection. Infections caused by Vancomycin Resistant Enterococci (VRE) that become resistant to both Vancomycin and Teicoplanin they are known as Glycopeptide Resistant Enterococci (GRE). The infection control principles for
individual cases or when there are clusters are the same for VRE and GRE therefore for the purposes of this policy the term VRE will be used.
Scope
This policy aims to guide staff in the safe management of patients who have laboratory proven or clinically suspected VRE infection and/or colonisation, in order to prevent transmission of infection

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust

Infection Prevention and Control Committee (IPCC) is responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has the necessary  management  systems  in  place  to  enable  the  effective implementation  of this  policy  and  overall  responsibility  for  the  health  and safety of staff, patients and visitors
The  Director  for  Infection  Prevention  and  Control  (DIPC)  will  have operational responsibility for the effective implementation of this policy
The Head of Nursing for Infection Prevention and Control
Oversee infection control policies and their implementation
Responsible for infection prevention and control teams across the MSE
Reports directly to the Head of Harm Free Care
Challenge inappropriate hygiene practice and antibiotic prescribing
Assess impact of plans/policies on infection prevention and control
Member of clinical governance structures

The Infection Prevention and Control Teams (IPCT) are responsible for ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy and advising ward staff on control measures, providing them with the necessary advice
Microbiology Department
The microbiology laboratory and Consultant microbiologists are responsible for:
Ensuring that appropriate tests are available for identification of VRE
Ensuring that results are communicated promptly to clinical teams
Providing timely advice to clinicians regarding appropriate treatment, where relevant
Monitoring the use of antimicrobial agents within the Trust and feedback on areas for improvement
Clinical Site Management Team
The Clinical Site Management team are responsible for:
Assisting ward staff to identify single room accommodation for patients with VRE where risk assessment has shown that this is appropriate.

All Staff must comply with this policy and act in a responsible manner, liaising with the IPCT in a timely manner if in need of advice or support. All staff have a responsibility to ensure that infection prevention and control is embedded into their everyday practice and applied consistently at all times
Risk Factors and Transmission of GRE/VRE

Enterococci (Enterococcus species) are a group of bacteria naturally present in the intestinal tract of humans and normally cause no harm (colonisation). However sometimes enterococci can cause infections in wounds, urine and in more serious infections in blood. Most infections are caused by the patient's own bacteria but cross-infection between patients in hospital can happen.
VRE are enterococci that are resistant to an antibiotic called Vancomycin. VRE are often resistant to other types of antibiotics
Colonisation  is the presence, growth and multiplication of the bacteria without observable signs or symptoms of infections.
Infections refer to invasion of the bacteria into the patient tissues with signs or symptoms of infection/illness.
Most  Enterococci  infections, including VRE are endogenous but cross infection between patients can occur as follows:
Transmission via environmental contamination
Healthcare workers hands
Direct patient to patient contact
Equipment such as thermometers, commodes
Those patients at high risk of acquiring VRE colonisation/infection are:
Critically ill patients
Patients with severe underlying disease or immuno-suppression such as patients in Critical Care Units and Oncology Departments.
Patients who have had intra-abdominal or surgical procedures
Patients with permanent indwelling urinary catheters
Patients with a prolonged hospital stay
Patients who have had multi-antimicrobial and/or Vancomycin therapy
Underlying disease especially hepatobiliary disease
Patients  with  permanent  indwelling  percutaneous  endoscopic gastroscopy tubes
Surveillance and screening

Routine  trust-wide  admission  screening  is  currently  not  recommended. However, selective admission and/or interval screening on high risk groups may be undertaken on advice of infection control service.
Screening during suspected outbreaks and in response to important incidents will be at request of Infection Control Doctor/Consultant Microbiologist.
Procedures required for managing VRE
Isolation

7.1.1 Patients  should  be  risk  assessed  for  the  need  for  isolation.  If  deemed necessary a side room facility preferably with an en-suite toilet facility should be requested, if there is no en-suite toilet facility, a commode should be dedicated for use only by the patient.
7.1.2 Gloves  and  aprons  must  be  worn  by  staff  for  direct  patient  contact  and cleaning  the  environment.  Protective  clothing  must  be  removed  prior  to leaving the room.
7.1.3 It is unnecessary to wear protective clothing for activities that do not involve significant patient or environmental contact, e.g. giving oral medication.
7.1.4 Hands must be washed immediately after glove removal
7.1.5 The door should be left closed whenever possible and must be kept closed during all procedures.
7.1.6 A ‘Standard Precaution' notice should be placed on the outside of the door.
7.1.7 Patients receiving renal dialysis to be dialysed in a single room
7.1.8 Long sleeved gowns and masks are not required
7.1.9 Dedicated equipment must be used and wherever possible disposable/single use.

7.1.10 Non-disposable equipment (e.g. stethoscopes, lifting slings) that is required for care, must be decontaminated upon leaving the room (refer to the Decontamination Policy), or preferably designated for the patient's sole use during their hospital stay.
Commode/Toilet Hygiene
7.2.1 It is important that commode chairs are cleaned after every use. This is because they may become contaminated or be contaminated and cross infection will occur.

7.2.2 The commode should be cleaned with a detergent wipe, and then cleaned with a solution of DIFFX /or Tristel jet spray in order to ensure that it is decontaminated and stored as clean i.e. with the commode arms out and the seat up turned.

7.2.3 The toilet must be kept clean and free from faecal deposits, as cross infection may occur via this route. Any contamination must be reported immediately and action taken to clean the area as soon as possible.
Linen and Waste Disposal
7.3.1 All soiled linen must be placed in a pink alginate bag prior to placing into a white plastic laundry bag for laundering.
7.3.2 All other soiled waste should be disposed of into an orange clinical waste bag
Hand Decontamination
7.4.1 Hands should be decontaminated using soap and water or hand sanitiser before and after every contact with the patient, their immediate environment and their equipment
7.4.2 Patients must be offered hand washing facilities after using the toilet or commode and before eating.
Room Cleaning
7.5.1 Daily cleaning should take place with a solution of DiffX, paying particular attention to high touch points such as door handles, by the Ward Domestic
7.5.2 Once a patient has been discharged, the room should undergo a terminal clean
Treatment
7.6.1  Antibiotic treatment will be advised on an individual patient basis by the Consultant Microbiologist.
Transfers

7.7.1  Transfers of patients to other wards/departments/Trusts should be kept to a minimum unless necessary for clinical care. In such a case, the receiving ward/department should be informed by the nurse in charge of the ward/department transferring the patient, prior to transfer.
Visitors

7.8.1 Nursing staff must inform the patient/next of kin of the reason for the isolation precautions being taken, and then contact the IPCT in order that an Infection Control Nurse can attend the ward to explain the VRE to the patient/next of kin.
7.8.2 Family and friends of the patient must be advised on hand washing when leaving the isolation room.
7.8.3 Gloves and apron are only required for use when giving direct care.
Outbreak Management

7.9.1  If an outbreak of VRE infection/colonisation is suspected a number of actions to assist with the investigation and control of the incident will need to be undertaken as per Outbreak Policy. The IPCT will advise
Death
7.10.1  Infection Control precautions apply to deceased patients as in life. No specific precautions are required if the patient has VRE when they die.
Training Requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates and Donning and Doffing updates. The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE IPCC's with the authority to approve MSE policies. These will then be forwarded to the  Document  control  team  for  submission  and  ratification  by  the  Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director of Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
